page.title: 18HALMYRE FARM
page.content: Halmyre is a large farm of 328 acres. It is a mixed farm that produces milk from dairy cows, crops and sometimes vegetables. There are three employees: one dairyman, one tractorman and one general worker. The farmer's daily routine during the winter is usually as follows: start at six o'clock, feed young calves then feed stirks and calf heifers. He then scrapes out the shed and beds them with hay. Then he gives dairy cows and young calves silage. When this is done he does a seasonal job such as slurrying before feeding the calves again at half past four in the afternoon. Of the 328 acres, 24 are barley, 16 are hay, 94 are silage and 186 are grass. There are 150 dairy cows, called Ayrshires, and six bulls.
